sub_title: Artistic Director at SNDO - School for New Dance Development

school.name: DasArts (currently DAS Theatre), Amsterdam University of the Arts

education.field_of_study: Contemporary dance, movement and theatre workshops

awards.title: 2nd Prize at the Choreographic Competition
awards.description:
At the second edition of the Choreographic Competition in Belgrade I felt it honourable to enrol in the competition which I won pervious year to pay respect to the organisation and the audience. Then I ended up getting a prize again, this time 2nd place.
I concluded that from here, apparently, things go downwards when it comes to winning prizes so I didn't enrol into the competition further :).

I happily returned as jury member in 2015 :)

The 1998 work was made in collaboration with members of KPGT dance theatre a.o. with Sanja Vinkovic, Greta Trefalt, Aleksandra Petosevic and Jelena Milanovic Cirica.

awards.title: 1st Prize at the Choreographic Competition
awards.description:
Lots of firsts: with my first attempt at making a choreographic work I enrolled into the first edition of the Festival of Choreographic short-form hosted by Association of Dance Artists of Serbia. I won the first prize :).

This resulted in being offered to create my first full-length choreographic work for the Chamber stage of the National Theatre in Belgrade. I suggested to director of ballet Lidija Pilipenko, that I would like to share the evening with a talented colleague Isidora Stanisic. This was the birth of double bill "Osame' which was for 7 years on the repertory of National Theatre in Belgrade.

The 10 minute winning piece which opened doors for what today I consider my career, was made in collaboration with dancers Isidora Stanisic and Dusan Muric. My cousin made the costumes and we played Coldcut Ninja Tune mix and Amanda Lear's song 'Follow me' without copyright permissions and distorted by playing the single instead on 45 on 33 turns. Youth :)

profile_positions.description:
Responsible for the artistic and general policy and study program. Leads the team of 7 core staff members, 50 freelance artists/educators and 35 to 40 students annually.

The SNDO - School for New Dance Development - offers a full time four-year professional education course leading to a Bachelor's degree in Art – Choreography.

The school was founded in 1975 as an attempt to find new directions for dance next to the existing forms and styles that dominated the field. After forty years, the SNDO remains inquisitive, open minded, and in the foreground of progressive developments in the fields of dance and performance.The programme fosters experimentation and critical reflection and guides students to develop their own artistic practice as well as to contribute to the development of the dance and performance field at large.
profile_positions.title: Artistic Director - SNDO - School for New Dance Development, Academy of Theatre and Dance

company.name: Moving Together: Activism, Art and Education - A Week with Angela Davis

profile_positions.company: Moving Together: Activism, Art and Education - A Week with Angela Davis
profile_positions.description:
A weeklong program was taking place at various arts, cultural, educational and heritage institutions, and community centers in Amsterdam and Utrecht. Together with esteemed guest Professor Angela Y. Davis, and Professor Gina Dent as well as artists, scholars, activists and audience members, we looked into questions of citizenship, communal knowledge sharing, intergenerational activism, and related artistic practices. The aim was to gather and create connections between different anti-racist practices, organisations, communities and individuals. 
The programs had great resonances throughout the city and gathered more than 2000 people in the scope of the week.
Program was initiated by SNDO - School for New Dance Development and produced by the Academy of Theatre and Dance as part of AIR - Artist in Residence program of the Amsterdam University of the Arts and the Research Center for Material Culture (Nationaal Museum voor Wereldculturen).

The project was generously supported by Democracy and Media Foundation and Mama Cash with contributions of the Netherlands Institute for Cultural Analysis, Amsterdam Centre for Globalisation Studies, the ASCA Research Group Transformations of Civil Disobedience: Democratization, Globalization, Digitalization, VU University Amsterdam, Organisation of the Research Institute for Culture, History and Heritage, CLUE+, BAK Utrecht, Framer Framed, the Black Archives and the Black Heritage Tours.

Curated by Amal Alhaag, Quinsy Gario, Nadia Bekkers, Mikki Stelder and Bojana Mladenovic.
profile_positions.title: Initiator, executive producer, member of the curatorial team

profile_positions.description: Member of the Jury of 52nd edition of International Theatre Festival BITEF alongside Aleksandra Jaknovic, Bryce Lease, Judit Czaki and Radmila Vojvodic.
profile_positions.title: Jury member

profile_positions.description:
Performance Platform was a website and webapp listing public activities from four different organisations based in Amsterdam: Het Veem Theater, NBprojects, If I Can't Dance, DasArts and SNDO. In addition, it called attention to other performance-related events in the city and abroad. Performance Platform was an entirely subjective, but broadly oriented mapping of the performance landscape. More than a user-friendly listing, it opened up existing pathways through the city and invited discovery across the various institutions where (performing) arts took place. Far from attempting an all-encompassing survey of the field, we included performance-related activities that have captured our imagination: mainly in Amsterdam – to strengthen the local scene – but also elsewhere in the world through our picks and recommendations.
We drew attention to the things that are already here, close-by, but which are perhaps overlooked, inconspicuous or as yet unnoticed. Every month a new landscape of artistic activity arose; full of not-yet-visible links and possible interconnections, new perspectives, viewpoints and secret gardens.

The platform contents were curated by the editorial board of Barbara van Lindt, Frédérique Bergholtz, Nicole Beutler, Bojana Mladenovic and later joined by Anne Breure. In last phase we invited a completely new editorial board consisting of a new generation of perfromance makers, thinker and curators: Annick Kleizen, Simon Assencio, Marjolein Vogels, Maria Roessler and Isobel Dryburgh.
profile_positions.title: Initiator, co-producer, member of the Editorial Board

profile_positions.description: Alongside Mamoru Sakata, Maciej Kuźmiński, Ana Ignjatović Zagorac and Sanja Ninković.
profile_positions.title: Jury chairperson

profile_positions.description:
Setting up and executing the artistic and general policy. Leading the team of 7-10 staff members and up to 20-30 freelance artists on annual basis. 

Het Veem Theater (now Veem House for Performance) is an Amsterdam based production house providing support to younger generation of choreographers and perfromance makers working within the experimental and progressive part of the performing arts spectrum. 

During this period (2010-2014) the house made the leap forwards through the severe national budget cuts of 2011. It was one of the rare places (out of 23 production houses in the Netherlands) that managed to secure both local (Municipality of Amsterdam) and national (Fonds Podiumkunsten) structural support onwards.
Further, in this period the house joined the Culture Europe supported network Life Long Burning as well as established a large number of local and international partnerships and collaborations.

Hitherto locally oriented and somewhat quiet in its presence in the filed, within four years the house became a vibrant gathering place for art students, visual artists, critical thinkers, performers, it became a household name within the European progressive performing arts venues and festivals scene, while maintaining serious efforts to open its doors for its neighbourhood and its surrounding community.
profile_positions.title: Artistic and Managing Director

profile_positions.description:
Reflecting on the development of performing arts in Amsterdam, we can trace a history
back to the impact that this city has had on international, groundbreaking innovations:
from the radical Actie Tomaat (Tomato Campaign) in the 1960s to the avant-garde
theatre produced by the Mickery theatre in the 70s and 80s; and in the fruitful
cooperation between European players that gave rise to new networks, artistic alliances
and experimental educational programmes such as Amsterdam’s Mime school, SNDO,
Masters of Choreography and DasArts.
And every year again, the Amsterdam theatre and dance schools continue to attract
young artists from all over the world. 
However, in recent years we have witnessed changes, with more and more professionals
moving away from Amsterdam soon after graduation to continue their career in cities
such as Brussels or Berlin, often remaining nomadic and responsive to opportunities and
projects. The conference attempted to investigate if this is exclusively a local problem, or is it also a symptom of the precarious conditions for artists in other European capitals?

BER-AMS-BXL was a collaboration and co-production between three Amsterdam-based organizations: Het Veem Theater, Flemish Arts Centre De Brakke Grond and the Theatre and Dance research group at de Theaterschool, Amsterdam. Supported by Goethe Institut, HZT Berlin, Amsterdam’s School for New Dance Development (SNDO) and Amsterdam Master of Choreography (AMCh). BER-AMS-BXL events - The Performance Situation Room and Critical Practice - at Het Veem Theater were part of the Life Long Burning (LLB) project, supported by the Culture Programme of the European Union. The conference was promoted by the Nederlands Theater Festival 2013.
Curated by Marijke Hoogenboom, Piet Menu, Tom Rummens and Bojana Mladenović with grateful thanks to Gabriël Smeets, Jeroen Fabius, Barbara van Lindt and Loes van der Pligt.
profile_positions.title: Initiator, executive producer, member of the curatorial team

profile_positions.description: Member of the selection committees for prospective studenst of DasArts (now DAS Theatre), AMCh (now DAS Choreography) and SNDO - School for New Dance Development.

profile_positions.description:
Tre Tigri is a loose association of artists: Alex Zakkas, Esther Mugambi, Janneke Raaphorst and Sarah van Lamsweerde.
Although each artist works in between disciplines, and this ‘undisciplined’ approach is what connects them, the field of performance is where their paths often meet.

Tre Tigri is part of a larger fauna of artists and friends, notably Bojana Mladenović and Norberto Llopis Segarra who were part of the initial founding group of Tre Tigri.
profile_positions.title: Co-initiator and associate artist

profile_positions.description:
Maker of performances 'One piece', 'Violet' en 'Vincent and me', produced by Frascati Theater and presented within Something Raw Festival.

Collaborator and performer in works of a.o. Nicole Beutler, Ivana Müller, David Weber-Krebs en Sarah van Lamsweerde.
profile_positions.title: Performance maker, collaborator and performer
